articles.headline: Biden Defends ‘Difficult’ Decision to Send Cluster Munitions to Ukraine
articles.snippet: With Ukraine burning through stockpiles of conventional artillery, President Biden concluded that he had little choice but to provide the weapons.
articles.abstract: With Ukraine burning through stockpiles of conventional artillery, President Biden concluded that he had little choice but to provide the weapons.
articles.lead_paragraph: President Biden defended his decision on Friday to provide Ukraine with cluster munitions, which are outlawed by many of America’s closest allies, saying it was a difficult decision but “the Ukrainians are running out of ammunition” in the fight against Russian forces.
articles.byline: By Katie Rogers and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: A Top U.K. Newspaper Explores Its Ties to Slavery, and Britain’s
articles.snippet: In a multimedia series, The Guardian becomes the latest British institution to confront — and apologize for — its role in the slave trade.
articles.abstract: In a multimedia series, The Guardian becomes the latest British institution to confront — and apologize for — its role in the slave trade.
articles.lead_paragraph: It is the kind of historical artifact that would be easy to miss: an old and fragile little book unearthed in the archives of the Derbyshire Record Office, in the East Midlands of England. The book, a commercial ledger from 1822, holds the names of enslavers who ran cotton plantations on islands along the coast of Florida, Georgia and South Carolina.

articles.headline: One Reason the U.S. Can’t Quit China? Chips.
articles.snippet: Chipmakers are finding it increasingly hard to operate in China but say doing business in the country is still key to their survival.
articles.abstract: Chipmakers are finding it increasingly hard to operate in China but say doing business in the country is still key to their survival.
articles.lead_paragraph: In May, Micron Technologies, the Idaho chipmaker, suffered a serious blow as part of the U.S.-China technology war. The Chinese government barred companies that handle crucial information from buying Micron’s chips, saying the company had failed a cybersecurity review.

articles.headline: After Supreme Court Rulings, Answering Reader Questions About Paying for College
articles.snippet: Responses to queries about financial aid, 529 plans, need-blind schools and more.
articles.abstract: Responses to queries about financial aid, 529 plans, need-blind schools and more.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court decisions that struck down affirmative action programs and President Biden’s student debt cancellation plan will affect millions of people, whether they’re about to apply for college or are trying to pay it off.
articles.byline: By Ron Lieber and Tara Siegel Bernard

articles.headline: Trump and DeSantis Are Battling for Iowa Voters. And for Its Governor, Too.
articles.snippet: Gov. Kim Reynolds has vowed to be neutral in 2024. But Donald Trump’s team views her as neutral in name only when it comes to Ron DeSantis and his wife.
articles.abstract: Gov. Kim Reynolds has vowed to be neutral in 2024. But Donald Trump’s team views her as neutral in name only when it comes to Ron DeSantis and his wife.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Kim Reynolds, the Republican governor of Iowa, stopped by a donor retreat that Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida held last year, no one paid it much mind.
articles.byline: By Shane Goldmacher, Jonathan Swan and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: The Mango Is King of the Miami Summer
articles.snippet: Those who sweat and suffer through June and July in South Florida are rewarded with mangoes blushing from trees in yards, streets and strip malls.
articles.abstract: Those who sweat and suffer through June and July in South Florida are rewarded with mangoes blushing from trees in yards, streets and strip malls.
articles.lead_paragraph: The air gets thick with humidity as summer arrives in South Florida. Evening thunder murmurs. The tropics begin to stir.
articles.byline: By Patricia Mazzei and James Jackman

articles.headline: Far-Right Parties Are Rising to Power Around Europe. Is Spain Next?
articles.snippet: As Spain prepares for elections, some liberal European politicians fear that the hard-right Vox party could become the first right-wing party since the Franco era to enter Spain’s national government.
articles.abstract: As Spain prepares for elections, some liberal European politicians fear that the hard-right Vox party could become the first right-wing party since the Franco era to enter Spain’s national government.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last month, after Spain’s conservative and hard-right parties crushed the left in local elections, the winners in Elche, a small southeastern town known for an ancient sculpture and shoe exports, signed an agreement with consequences for the future of Spain — and the rest of Europe.

articles.headline: China and the U.S., Still Adversaries, Are Talking. That’s a Start.
articles.snippet: Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen, after 10 hours of meetings with Chinese officials, said the two sides would pursue “more frequent communication” despite their deep differences.
articles.abstract: Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen, after 10 hours of meetings with Chinese officials, said the two sides would pursue “more frequent communication” despite their deep differences.
articles.lead_paragraph: Treasury Secretary Janet L. Yellen came to China amid hopes that the United States could restart a relationship that has been deteriorating for years and had gotten off the rails recently over significant points of tension — including the war in Ukraine, a Chinese spy balloon that flew over U.S. territory and was shot down by the American military, and the two countries’ escalating exchange of restrictions on trade.
articles.byline: By Alan Rappeport and Keith Bradsher

articles.headline: For North Koreans in China, Seeking Freedom Is More Perilous Than Ever
articles.snippet: Recent efforts to help people escape Kim Jong-un’s regime via China have been thwarted by digital surveillance, profiteering and the pandemic.
articles.abstract: Recent efforts to help people escape Kim Jong-un’s regime via China have been thwarted by digital surveillance, profiteering and the pandemic.
articles.lead_paragraph: The North Korean software engineer was desperate.

articles.headline: Where Clarence Thomas Entered an Elite Circle and Opened a Door to the Court
articles.snippet: The exclusive Horatio Alger Association brought the justice access to wealthy members and unreported V.I.P. treatment. He, in turn, offered another kind of access.
articles.abstract: The exclusive Horatio Alger Association brought the justice access to wealthy members and unreported V.I.P. treatment. He, in turn, offered another kind of access.
articles.lead_paragraph: On Oct. 15, 1991, Clarence Thomas secured his seat on the Supreme Court, a narrow victory after a bruising confirmation fight that left him isolated and disillusioned.
articles.byline: By Abbie VanSickle and Steve Eder

articles.headline: For a President and a King, the View From the Top Is Curiously Similar
articles.snippet: Despite hints of tension between Washington and London, President Biden and King Charles III share interests and have faced comparable challenges, which might have helped smooth their meeting.
articles.abstract: Despite hints of tension between Washington and London, President Biden and King Charles III share interests and have faced comparable challenges, which might have helped smooth their meeting.
articles.lead_paragraph: The two men — the American president and the British king — waited decades for their dream jobs, projecting a sense of normalcy and unity when they finally reached their thrones. They both prefer to ditch executive palaces for their respective retreats. And they share a passion for confronting threats to the environment.
articles.byline: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs and Mark Landler

articles.headline: How Biden Might Try to Cancel Student Debt Next
articles.snippet: The administration proposed to use its “compromise and settlement” powers under the Higher Education Act of 1965. But what does that mean?
articles.abstract: The administration proposed to use its “compromise and settlement” powers under the Higher Education Act of 1965. But what does that mean?
articles.lead_paragraph: On June 30, in the wake of losing a Supreme Court lawsuit over his $400 billion plan to cancel student loan debt, President Biden said he was going to try again.

articles.headline: The Case That Could Be Fox’s Next Dominion
articles.snippet: Tucker Carlson, before he was sidelined by Fox, repeatedly endorsed a conspiracy theory about an Arizona man, who may sue for defamation. Legal experts say it would be a viable case.
articles.abstract: Tucker Carlson, before he was sidelined by Fox, repeatedly endorsed a conspiracy theory about an Arizona man, who may sue for defamation. Legal experts say it would be a viable case.
articles.lead_paragraph: Of all the distortions and paranoia that Tucker Carlson promoted on his since-canceled Fox News program, one looms large: a conspiracy theory that an Arizona man working as a covert government agent incited the Jan. 6, 2021, assault on the Capitol to sabotage and discredit former President Donald J. Trump and his political movement.
articles.byline: By Jeremy W. Peters and Alan Feuer

articles.headline: How a Distant War Is Threatening Livelihoods in the Arctic Circle
articles.snippet: The fighting in Ukraine has disrupted a region in northern Norway that had thrived on cross-border trade and cooperation with Russia.
articles.abstract: The fighting in Ukraine has disrupted a region in northern Norway that had thrived on cross-border trade and cooperation with Russia.
articles.lead_paragraph: In this corner of Norway’s far north, just five miles from the border with Russia, road signs give directions in Norwegian and Russian. Locals are used to crossing from one country to the other visa-free: Norwegians to fill up on cheap Russian gasoline; Russians to hit the Norwegian malls.
articles.byline: By Melissa Eddy and Patrick Junker

articles.headline: Turkey Clears the Way for Sweden’s Entry to NATO on the Eve of Summit
articles.snippet: The announcement allows the military alliance to project unity, which is getting harder to sustain as the war in Ukraine goes on.
articles.abstract: The announcement allows the military alliance to project unity, which is getting harder to sustain as the war in Ukraine goes on.
articles.lead_paragraph: Turkey agreed on Monday to clear the way for Sweden to join NATO, a sudden reversal that allows the alliance to project an image of unity and expansion on the eve of a critical summit intended to prepare for what could be a long war to repel Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger, Steven Erlanger, Ben Hubbard and Lara Jakes

articles.headline: The New York Times to Disband Its Sports Department
articles.snippet: Coverage of games, players and leagues will now come primarily from The Athletic, the sports website that the company bought last year.
articles.abstract: Coverage of games, players and leagues will now come primarily from The Athletic, the sports website that the company bought last year.
articles.lead_paragraph: The New York Times said on Monday that it would disband its sports department and rely on coverage of teams and games from its website The Athletic, both online and in print.
articles.byline: By Katie Robertson and John Koblin
